journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part H: Journal of Engineering in Medicine

title-group.article-title: Numerical study of the solidification process in biological tissue with blood flow and metabolism effects by the dual phase lag model

article-meta.aff: 1Young Researchers Club, Islamic Azad University, Arak Branch, Iran
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, University of Isfahan, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Amir Moradi, Islamic Azad University, Arak Branch, Young Researchers Club, Arak, Iran. Email: amirmoradi_hs@yahoo.com

abstract.p: The bioheat transfer with phase change in biological tissues during the freezing process is simulated by the dual phase lag conduction heat transfer model. A numerical algorithm based on the enthalpy method is established to solve the solidification of biological tissues. The linearly temperature-dependent enthalpy (non-isothermal phase change) is considered here. The results of the parabolic heat conduction model for a slice of cucumber are compared with the experimental data. A comparison between dual phase lag and hyperbolic solutions with small values of relaxation times is applied in order to verify the corresponding parabolic solutions accuracy of the dual phase lag and hyperbolic solutions. The heating source effect owing to blood perfusion and metabolic heat on the heat transfer in a biological tissue subject to freezing process is studied. The relaxation time has an important influence on the transient temperature and temperature gradient. A major discrepancy among bioheat transfer models is found for zones closer to the cooling boundary. The heat source term, owing to blood flow and metabolism in a phase change problem in the biological tissue, has a significant influence on thermal effects of the subject tissue.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The heat transfer involved in phase change is essential in biomedical applications. Cryopreservation and cryosurgery are both biological applications derived from heat transfer in tissues regarding phase transformation. Cryopreservation is applied to enhance survival of biological materials such as cell, tissues, organs, etc.;1,2 while cryosurgery is applied to destruct undesired tissues using a freezing process.3,4 During a typical cryopreservation, the tissues/cells are preserved with no significant damage to their function, such as mechanical properties, viability, etc.5–7 The common phenomena that occur during the tissues solidification process are intracellular and extra cellular ice formation. One of the common methods, which are suggested in preserving biological tissues, is freezing with a high cooling rate. Here, the ice crystallization and grain growth are not formed, but a second order thermodynamic phase transition leads to an arrest in the translational molecular motions. The frozen region tends to form amorphous ice that is said to have vitrified or formed glass. Increasing the temperature gradient at the cooling boundary is a significant approach adopted by some researchers8,9 in order to achieve a freezing process with a high cooling rate.

Solid–liquid phase change phenomenon occurs in an extensive range of technical applications, such as metal processing, welding and environmental applications. When phase change occurs, a major difficulty is the discontinuity of temperature and the unknown position of the solid–liquid interface.10 A limited number of analytical solutions exist for phase change problems that are one-dimensional (1D). The exact solutions for phase change in biological tissues were presented by Rubinsky and Shitzer11 and Rabin and Shitzer.12 Sadd and Didlake13 studied melting of a semi-infinite body that was exposed to sudden temperature differences by the hyperbolic heat conduction problem and compared the results with the results obtained by the parabolic model. The complexity of multidimensional phase change in biological tissues should be solved by numerical techniques. Two basic approaches that are applied in solving phase change problems numerically, are the moving interface tracking technique14,15 and enthalpy method.16,17

In recent years, phase change problems of biological tissues during freezing has gained interest among many researchers. The crystallization process during food freezing using the Fourier heat conduction model and enthalpy method was studied by Sanz and de Elvira.18 Deng and Liu19 investigated the effect of a non-Fourier model on transient temperature prediction and thermal stress. They solved the governing equations by adopting an implicit finite difference method and a continuous temperature at the solid–liquid interface.13,20 The apparent heat capacity approach is one of the other techniques applied in solving the phase change problems numerically. Wang et al.21 adopted this approach to simulate the individual food freezing time in the freezing process. Kumar and Katiyar22 studied the effect of a porous medium on the heat transfer phase change. They applied the apparent heat capacity method to simulate the freezing process. They observed a decrease in freezing and heating rate with an increase in porosity value. The freezing problems in biological tissue must include the thermal effect of blood perfusion and metabolic heat generation in the unfrozen region. Deng and Liu23 carried out a three-dimensional (3D) numerical simulation of combined cryosurgery and hyperthermia therapy. They applied the effective heat capacity approach in order to solve the governing equations and the 1D exact solution for a semi-infinite region to validate the numerical code. Thakur et al.24 presented a meshless local Petrov-Galerkin (MLPG) method to solve phase change heat transfer in a freezing process. They compared their results with that of the 1D exact solution and finite element results and found a good agreement between them. Deng and Liu25 conducted the effect of large blood vessels on a 3D temperature profile during cryosurgery in different vascular models. They observed that the different vascular models produce a significantly different transient temperature for a freezing pattern. Zhao et al.26 applied the enthalpy method to simulate a multidimensional heat transfer problem during cryosurgery. They applied the finite element method to discretize the governing equations and studied the blood perfusion effect and metabolic heat on temperature and temperature gradient of the subject tissue. They observed a significant influence on the thermal history of the subject tissue owing to blood flow and metabolism.

The purpose of this study is to simulate the 1D heat transfer problem during the solidification process. The phase change heat transfer in a biological tissue is solved numerically by adopting the enthalpy method by the dual phase lag (DPL) model. The analysis of the phase change in biological tissues has not been pursued by the DPL model. In most studies, the parabolic bioheat transfer model is applied for simulating the phase change problem in the solidification process. The blood flow effect and metabolic heat source on the temperature history and other important characteristics are studied here. In this study, the temperature-dependent enthalpy (non-isothermal phase change) is applied in order to simulate heat transfer in the freezing process. In most solidification systems, the phase change from liquid to solid, and the accompanying evolution of latent heat, will occur over a temperature range where both the solid and liquid phases coexist. Here, the linear evolution of the latent heat over the solidification range is applied for the non-isothermal phase change.

sec.title: The DPL heat transfer formulation for the enthalpy method during the freezing process
sec.p: The heat transfer problem with phase transformation phenomena in biological tissues has been studied by many researchers18–26 by solving the parabolic bioheat transfer equation during the solidification process. Deng and Liu19 studied the effect of the hyperbolic model on temperature and thermal stress history. They solved the problem by an implicit finite difference method, where the temperature discontinuity at the moving phase change interface was ignored. In this study, the DPL model is applied in order to simulate the freezing process. The blood flow and metabolism effects are considered here.
The 1D DPL heat transfer with blood perfusion and metabolic heat generation effect applied in the enthalpy method is expressed by

where, ρ and C are the density and specific heat, respectively. In a two phase control volume, a combination of thermal conductivity coefficients is calculated by

where, ksl is the combinational thermal conductivity of the two phase control volume with the volume fraction of liquid f. The enthalpy, esl, specific heat, Csl and density, ρsl of the two phase control volume are expressed by the following equations

where, s, l and sl are indices for solid, liquid and combinational phases, respectively. In general, the enthalpy can depend on different parameters such as temperature, cooling rate, heating rate, etc.

sec.title: Non-isothermal phase change
sec.p:
The enthalpy method arrives at a better solution when a solidification process occurs in a specific temperature range. In a non-isothermal phase change, the fusion occurs over the temperature range Ts<T<Tl, where,
T
l
and
T
s
are the thawing and freezing temperatures, respectively. The volume fraction f changes from being a step function to other forms that may or may not contain a discontinuity. When T<Ts, the enthalpy function is calculated by

where, Tref is the reference temperature. In this case, since the whole control volume is the solid phase, the latent heat is not considered; hence, the volume fraction of the unfrozen phase is zero. In many systems, it is reasonable to assume that the liquid fraction is just a temperature function.27 In this study, the linear temperature-dependent enthalpy is applied for the non-isothermal phase change. The enthalpy function for two phase regions is defined by
where, HL is the latent heat of phase change and is defined by

where L is the latent heat of the whole phase change process. When the material temperature is greater than that of the thawing temperature
( T >

)

sec.title: The numerical solution
sec.p: The enthalpy method for the parabolic heat transfer model in one and multidimensional problems was solved numerically by means of the implicit and explicit finite difference scheme.29–32 One basic approach to solve phase change problems is adoption of the enthalpy method. Easy development of multidimensional and other heat transfer models are the advantages of this method. The explicit form of the finite difference method is applied to discretize the energy equation; thus, equation (1) can be discretized as follows

The von Neumann analysis33 is carried out for stability analysis and can provide necessary stability criterion for a numerical scheme expressed by34

where, αs and αl are thermal diffusivity of solid and liquid phases, respectively. The stability criterion of equation (13) is derived for one phase and without heat sources. The following assumptions are made during the mathematical solution of the model.23,24,35–36

list-item.p: The phase change of biological tissue during the solidification process occurs at a certain temperature range Ts–Tl.35Ts and Tl are given in Table 1.
The densities of the frozen and unfrozen zone are the same and the volume changes caused by the phase changes are completely ignored.
The blood perfusion and metabolic heat generation are considered before phase transformation.36
An independent-temperature thermal conductivity is assigned to the frozen and unfrozen regions with different values of thermal conductivities.

sec.title: Validation and case study of the numerical solution
sec.p:
In this article, equation (1) is solved numerically by adopting parabolic, hyperbolic and DPL heat transfer models. The DPL model is reduced to the hyperbolic model where
τ
T
= 0
is reduced to the parabolic model where both relaxation times
τ
T
and
τ
q
equal zero.

In order to validate of modeling and numerical simulation, a slice of cucumber is considered. The numerical code accuracy is validated through comparison of the obtained results with the experimental data obtained by Tu and Liu37 for a slice of cucumber. Wang et al.21 applied this experimental data to validate of their simulation results. The cucumber thickness is 2.5 cm and the insulated boundary condition at the center of cucumber (x = 1.25 cm). Convection condition with air temperature 233 K and convective heat transfer coefficient h = 280 W/m2 K at the surface of cucumber
( x = 0 )
, are considered as the boundary conditions for numerical solution. The initial temperature is T0 = 293 K. The properties of the cucumber are presented in Wang et al.21 and Tu and Liu.37 The central temperature of the cucumber slice (temperature at x = 1.25 cm) of the test object versus time for numerical and experimental analysis is shown in Figure 1. It is observed the experimental results are in good agreement with those calculated by the enthalpy method. It is worth mentioning that the obtained numerical results in the validated study are calculated from the parabolic heat transfer model with phase change during the solidification process.

caption.p: Comparison between the numerical and experimental37 central temperature of a slice of cucumber.

sec.p:
The 1D DPL heat transfer model, with blood perfusion and metabolic heat generation effect in a layer of skin tissue, is solved numerically. The schematic of biological tissue solidification is shown in Figure 2. For case study with respect to the DPL model,
τ
q
and
τ
T
are 0.3 s and 5 s, respectively. After running a grid-dependence test by using several mesh sizes, the space step Δx = 0.04 cm (equaling 51 nodes at x = 2 cm) was used for numerical solution. The time step
Δ t =
10
− 6
s
is selected for solidification simulation of biological tissues. The length of subject tissue in this case study is 2 cm, frozen symmetrically on both sides with constant temperature 77 K, and the initial tissue temperature is T0 = 300 K. The tissue properties correspond to Table 1.19,23,25,26

sec.title: The numerical results for the DPL non-isothermal phase change without blood flow and metabolism effect
sec.p:
In order to study heat transfer problems in biomaterials using the DPL bioheat transfer model, the biological tissue, as used in the section ‘Validation and case study of the numerical solution’, is selected for numerical solution. The surface temperature at
x = 0
drops to the fusion temperature of liquid nitrogen 77 K. The adiabatic condition is considered for the surface at x = 0.02 m. The heat flux relaxation time
τ
q
and the relaxation time of temperature gradient
τ
T
are 0.3 s and 5 s, respectively. The temperature profiles for three different points of tissue are shown in Figure 3. The points closer to the cooling boundary have a lower temperature than that of the farther points. It is clear that the solidification process for the area closer to the cooling boundary occurs in a shorter time than that of the farther one. Two important parameters here are the freezing velocity and freezing rate. The freezing velocity is the distance that the final point of the solidification process moves per unit of time; the freezing rate for each point of the tissue is defined by the amount of temperature drop during the complete solidification process per unit of time, and they are defined by

caption.p:
The variations of temperature versus time for three different points of subject tissue and DPL model (
τ

and

is the final time of solidification process at point i.

The temperature distribution along the tissue at different times of the solidification process is shown in Figure 4. It is observed that initially the end sections of the subject tissue do not freeze, while as time passes, the whole tissue freezes and the tissue temperature decreases. The variation of moving interface position versus time for the subject tissue is shown in Figure 5. As shown, the slope of profile decreases as time passes. When time increases the temperature gradient between the tissue and cooling boundary becomes smaller, thus the freezing velocity and slope of the freezing position profile decreases. The variation of freezing velocity with respect to time for the subject tissue is shown in Figure 6. Because the temperature gradient is initially severe, the freezing velocity varies sharply. As time goes on, the temperature gradient becomes weaker with a gradual change in freezing velocity.

sec.title: The effect of relaxation times on the freezing process
sec.p:
In order to investigate the effects of relaxation times on gradient temperature and temperature histories, a tissue with 0.5 cm thickness is selected for numerical solution. The tissue properties are presented in Table 1. The space and time steps are 0.04 cm and 10-6 s, respectively. The temperature profile at t = 25 s for both parabolic and hyperbolic models is shown in Figure 7. It is observed that as
τ
q
approaches zero, the hyperbolic solution approaches the parabolic solution. It can be deduced that, with a further decrease in
τ
q
, the hyperbolic solution would gradually approach the parabolic one. This is a rational way to validate the numerical scheme for the hyperbolic phase change problem. It is clear that the parabolic model predicts a lower temperature than that of the hyperbolic model temperature; and as the value of
τ
q
increases, the discrepancy between the predicted temperature via the parabolic and hyperbolic models becomes greater.

caption.p: Comparison of the target tissue temperature for both hyperbolic (τq=0.1s and τq=1s) and parabolic model when t = 25 s.

sec.p:
The position of the phase change interface during the freezing process for both parabolic and hyperbolic models with τq = 0.1 s and 1 s, and τT = 0 is shown in Figure 8. As illustrated, the phase change interface for the hyperbolic model moves slower than the parabolic one. This means that the time required for complete tissue solidification in the parabolic model is shorter than that of the hyperbolic model. The hyperbolic solution, with τq = 0.1 s, is very close to the parabolic solution as illustrated in Figure 7. A further decrease in freezing position is observed with an increase of value
τ
q
.

caption.p: Comparison of the moving interface position of tissue for both hyperbolic (τq = 0.1 s and τq = 1 s) and parabolic models.

sec.p:
The freezing velocity versus time for both parabolic and hyperbolic models is shown in Figure 9. It is observed that the freezing velocity for the parabolic model is higher in comparison with the hyperbolic model at the same time. As the value of
τ
q
increases more, the discrepancy between the parabolic and hyperbolic models becomes greater. As shown in Figure 9, the discrepancy between both the parabolic and hyperbolic models is initially clear. This is the result of an initial severe temperature gradient.

caption.p: The interface velocity of target tissue versus time for both hyperbolic (τq = 0.1 s and τq = 1 s) and parabolic models.

sec.p:
The cooling rate for both parabolic and hyperbolic models in the subject tissue is presented in Figure 10. As expected, the cooling rate for the parabolic model is greater than that of the hyperbolic one, and as the value of relaxation time
τ
q
increases, the cooling rate decreases drastically. Initially, the discrepancy between models is more evident; while as time goes on, this disparity between the models decreases (see Figure 9). Since obtaining an optimal heat transfer rate is significant in the freezing process, the transfer model types will have a high significance in calculating the freezing rate, especially at zones close to the cooling boundary.

caption.p: Comparison of freezing rate of the target tissue for both hyperbolic (τq = 0.1 s and τq = 1 s) and parabolic models.

sec.p:
Figure 11 illustrates how temperature profiles are affected by changes in the heat flux and temperature gradient relaxation times at t = 25 s. As time goes on, the discrepancy between the parabolic, hyperbolic and DPL models becomes more evident. The DPL model predicts a temperature higher than that of other models. The accuracy of the numerical code for the DPL model can be validated through a comparison between the DPL results and the small value of
τ
T
to the corresponding hyperbolic solution. As shown in Figure 11, the DPL solution for small values of
τ
T
gets closer to the hyperbolic solution.

caption.p: Comparison of the target tissue temperature for three models: DPL (τT = 0.3 s, τT = 1 s and τq = 0.3 s), hyperbolic (τq = 0.3 s) and parabolic when t = 25 s.

sec.p:
The position of the phase change interface for the subject tissue for three types of heat transfer models: parabolic, hyperbolic with τq = 0.3 s and DPL with τq = 0.3 s and τT = 0.3 s and 1 s is shown in Figure 12. It can clearly be seen that the DPL model for τT = 1 s moves faster than others during the initial solidification process. This phenomenon might be the overlap that is created through the thermal wave and its reflection at the tissue surface boundary. Furthermore, the temperature gradient is very steep at points close to the cooling boundary. As time passes, the temperature gradient becomes weaker and then the phase change position for the parabolic solution begins to advance towards the DPL interface for τT = 1 s and reaches x = 0.005 m first. The position of the phase changes for small values of
τ
T
and
τ
q
are very close to each other and are lower than the parabolic model.

caption.p: Comparison of the moving interface position of tissue for three models: DPL (τT = 0.3 s, τT = 1 s and τq = 0.3 s), hyperbolic (τq = 0.3 s) and parabolic.

sec.p: The freezing velocity versus time for three heat transfer models: parabolic, hyperbolic with τq = 0.3 s and DPL with τq = 0.3 s and τT = 0.3 and 1 s is shown in Figure 13. The freezing velocity for the DPL model (τT = 1 s) is initially greater than that of the parabolic model (Figure 12). As time passes, the predicted freezing velocity for the parabolic model would be higher, while the DPL model with τq = 0.3 s and τT = 0.3 s and the hyperbolic model (τq = 0.3 s) predict an interface velocity lower than that of the parabolic model. As times goes on, the discrepancy among the three models becomes smaller.

caption.p: The interface velocity of the target tissue versus time for three models: DPL (τT = 0.3 s,τT = 1 s and τq = 0.3 s), hyperbolic (τq = 0.3 s) and parabolic.

sec.p:
The freezing rate for the three models: parabolic, hyperbolic and DPL, for the subject tissue is shown in Figure 14. For points close to the cooling boundary, the disparity beyond all models is very clear and the DPL model predicts a cooling rate higher than that of the other models at those points where it leads to a violent temperature gradient. It is observed that, as the value of
τ
T
increases, the DPL model predicts a higher cooling rate at points closer to the cooling boundary. Here, it can be deduced that the initial temperature gradient is more severe compared with the later times, hence, initially, the relaxation times effect on the transient temperature and solidification process is stronger.

caption.p: Comparison of the freezing rate of the target tissue for three models: DPL (τT = 0.3 s,τT = 1 s and τq = 0.3 s), hyperbolic (τq = 0.3 s) and parabolic.

sec.title: The effect of blood perfusion and metabolic heat source on the freezing process
sec.p:
In order to study the effect of the heat source term of blood flow and metabolism in the bioheat transfer equation during the freezing process, a tissue of 0.5 cm thickness is selected for the numerical solution. The tissue properties are presented in Table 1. The space and time steps are selected as 0.04 cm and 10−6 s, respectively. The effect of
Q
on the transient temperature t = 25 s is shown in Figure 15 for the DPL (τq = 0.3 s and τT = 1 s) model. As illustrated, the blood perfusion and metabolism heat have a significant effect on prediction of transient temperature in the solidification process. It is evident that the DPL model, with a total heat source
Q
, has a higher temperature than the DPL model without a heat source. Figure 16 shows the effect of
Q
on the propagation of the freezing front for the DPL model. Here, it is observed that, with respect to the heat source term
Q
, the freezing position is obtained lower than that of the DPL model without
Q
. Zhao et al.26 have reported the same results with respect to the parabolic heat transfer model.

caption.p: The effect of the heat source term on tissue temperature for the DPL model when t = 25 s.
The effect of the heat source term on the freezing position of the target tissue for the DPL model.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this study an enthalpy method was developed and proposed in order to solve the 1D DPL heat conduction problem in biological tissues during freezing. The non-isothermal phase change was applied for solving the phase change problem. Numerical code accuracy for the parabolic model was validated through comparison of the calculated results with the experimental data, which were reported for a slice of cucumber.37 It is observed that the DPL solution for small values of relaxation times reaches to the parabolic solution. The results indicate that, because of the high cooling rate, the areas close to the cooling boundary require a shorter time for freezing than that of the areas away from cooling boundary. A slowdown in the freezing process was found owing to an increased value in relaxation times. The DPL results show that the freezing process for points close to the cooling boundary occurs more quickly in comparison with other models where it leads to a violent temperature gradient. As time passes away, the parabolic model begins to make an advance on the other models and requires a shorter time to complete solidification than others. The comprehensive computation results indicate that the freezing process takes longer when blood perfusion and metabolic heat generation are involved.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: C specific heat (J/kg K)
d differential element of integral
e enthalpy per unit volume (J/m3)
f volume fraction of unfrozen phase
h convective heat transfer coefficient (W/m2 K)
HL latent heat of phase change
k thermal conductivity (W/m K)
kaven average thermal conductivity at nodes i and i–l
kaves average thermal conductivity at nodes i and i+l
L latent heat (J/m3)
n time step
Q heat source (J/m3 s)
Qm metabolic heat (J/m3 s)
t time (s)
T tissue temperature (K)
Ta arterial and tissue temperatures (K)
Tc body core temperature
T0 initial temperature (K)
Tref reference temperature
x Cartesian coordinate (m)
α thermal diffusivity (m2/s)
Δx space step (cm)
Δt time step (s)
ρ density (kg/m3)
τq heat flux relaxation time (s)
τT temperature gradient relaxation time (s)
ωb lood perfusion rate (ml/s/ml)

c body core temperatures
i node indices
l liquid phase
s solid phase
sl two phase region
sur surrounding temperatures
